data.text: Can You Keep the Bicycle in Your Room when Staying at a Hotel?
A quick question. If staying at a hotel, are you able to keep your bicycle in the room?
I‚Äôve only been turned down twice. First time I just left and stayed elsewhere. Second time they let me keep it in a storage area that was locked so I stayed. Otherwise hasn‚Äôt ever been an issue.
data.author: Ty Dawley

data.text: Just ask them, most hotels have a boiler/store room or garage that they are happy for you to use. I also then lock it to something solid !
data.author: Alan Tucker

data.text: I've never asked, so yes
data.author: Eric Szilagyi

data.text: I have just booked a load and they all said I can‚Ä¶not tried yet though. Some chains some independent
data.author: Steven Orton

data.text: I don‚Äôt see why not. I‚Äôve done it at a motel before
data.author: Alex Olivares

data.text: I always did. Never had an issue.
data.author: Steve Farmer

data.text: Usually yes, or in a room where only staff has access.
data.author: Jean Flamand

data.text: Not all the time. Often it doesn‚Äôt fit in the elevator. Or the room is too small. Or your bike is too filthy and there‚Äôs no outdoor hose. They always seem to find a place for it.
data.author: Francesca Cohn

data.text: Never had an issue. Stayed with bike about 20 nights last year.
data.author: Jeff Osborn

data.text: I never ask. I just wheel mine in with me. I've never been told I couldn't. ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è
data.author: Angie Baker

data.text: Sometime in a locked shed or basement or back room if not on my room.
data.author: Christine Roche

data.text: Thank you for the information.
data.author: Bryan Kurz

data.text: If they dont, I'm not ü§î
data.author: Dave Buscarello

data.text: We run cycling holidays, we always make sure there is a bicycle storage facility before we book.
data.author: Peter South

data.text: I am asking before making a reservation. Some places don‚Äôt allow bikes in the room.
data.author: John Goldman

data.text: Yes Once years ago while I New York City we stayed at the Waldorf Astoria (it was a Hilton then) and kept our bikes in our room. They only asked us to use the freight elevator so we would not disturb the other guests. Have done the same in Wash DC, London, Paris. We also have checked them in at the concierge desk, which makes it easy when you want to bike around town.
data.author: George Manning

data.text: Yes
data.author: Christie Ogden

data.text: It has to sleep on the floor
data.author: Rick Turner

data.text: They carried it up the stairs to the room
data.author: David Atwell

data.text: Never been an issue for me.
data.author: Rich Meyer

data.text: Usually yes but not always
data.author: Scout Ess

data.text: I always make it a deal-breaker and have never been refused. Be sure to tell them it‚Äôs a BICYCLE, not a BIKE. Otherwise, they may think you want to bring a motorcycle into the room!
data.author: Tom Montalbano

data.text: or some dorty bitch they call the local bike.
data.author: Clayton Max Alexander

data.text: Absolutely. But in Europe it seems most small hotels have a room to overnight bicycles, at least that was the case in Portugal and Spain.
data.author: John Timothy Ratliffe

data.text: we found the same thing in France as well.
data.author: Lori Flynn Schaffhauser

data.text: and in Luxembourg too.
data.author: Doug Speer

data.text: Everyone l have ever stayed at, never even said anything to me as I walked in with it and went to my room. I would never have stayed otherwise.
data.author: Robert Provenzano

data.text: Depends on the hotel. I call ahead or book ahead and ask.
data.author: Tracy Murray Estes

data.text: Last hotel I stayed at in Hobart Tasmania Australia had a special room just for bicycles that you could access using your electronic room key. It also had 2 bike washing stations just outside the room. I tend to think bikes ridden in some areas would be too dirty and shouldn't be brought into the room.
data.author: Linda Gock

data.text: I would suggest if you take off the wheels and put a towel over it, then carry like a suitcase, then to should pass as hand luggage.
data.author: Brian Alexander Langton

data.text: I've never took my bike to any hotels so not sure, contact the hotels where you stay beforehand
data.author: Danny Simmons

data.text: Ask before paying
data.author: Jeff Flint

data.text: Im always asking before making booking. I try to see if they have ground floor room but when not I just Took with lift.
data.author: Julie Brincat Busuttil

data.text: Sure...we did in 3 different hotels.
data.author: David Sloneker

data.text: I always do
data.author: Shane Daly

data.text: Only if they want my money. :)
data.author: Rick Redding

data.text: Most hotels on the OTET are very accommodating!
data.author: Dean Bruewer

data.text: Never asked. Just took it in.
data.author: Sandi Donnenwirth Remson

data.text: right!!
data.author: Judi Schwandt

data.text: Always asked and was never told "no."
data.author: Bob Przetak

data.text: Yes always except sometimes they have a ground floor room you can leave it in the US. I have asked for old towels that they have to clean the bike or to place on the floor if it has been a nasty day for my bike
data.author: Gary Bicycles

data.text: Better to ask forgiveness than permission
data.author: Sue Hersman

data.text: Yes
data.author: Teresa Krinke Cheatham

data.text: I've never had an issue taking a bike into even fancy hotels, pretty sure I've never bothered asking though. Never brought one in particularly wet or dirty though.
data.author: Braden Graham

data.text: Have road around Malaysia and stayed in budget hotels, was pleasently surprised that some of the owners are cyclist themselves and allowed us to park our bikes in the laundry room, lobby and even in our rooms.
data.author: Peter Yang

data.text: Always
data.author: Jeff Neumann

data.text: Best to ask.
data.author: Danielle Bizjak

data.text: Always.
data.author: Patrick Francis

data.text: Yes
data.author: Patrick J McDonald

data.text: I always do if you don't want my bike you don't want my business same for restaurants
data.author: Robert Blodgett

data.text: , have to ask, even for restaurants??? I have never, ever, had a restaurant give me üëç to bring my bike in.
data.author: Darcy Therien

data.text: not at table but in secure location not going to risk $3000 bike for a meal If they can't accommodate i go elsewhere their choice
data.author: Robert Blodgett

data.text: Thanks! I was curious how that may work out for you, appreciate the response.
data.author: Darcy Therien

data.text: Usually it's no problem I even had a trailer with me when I was travelling across Canada
data.author: Shane Peebles

data.text: Some places they put your bike in storage. I stayed at a hostel in Venice Beach California they wanted me to keep my bike outside on third night it was gone :(
data.author: Shane Peebles

data.text: Depends on the hotel.
data.author: John Mcgarry

data.text: It isnt a "bicycle"....it is a "luggage cart" ;-)
data.author: Andy Decker

data.text: Yes
data.author: Jeff Keating

data.text: In the UK, Premier Inns (chain of cheap hotels) have an explicit policy to allow you to bring your bike into your room. üö¥‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è It helps if you remember to book a room on the ground floor too (disabled access). I understand that Travelodge and Holiday Inn are normally ok too, but I don't think that it is official policy for them.
data.author: Conor O'Neill

data.text: Yes üòé
data.author: Bruce Sturges

data.text:
Have slept at Hotel Checkpoint Charly. No Problems. And much space for Bicycle, too. Just as an Inspiration for Details go Click: www.3athletisches-und-triathletisches.blogspot.com full report in Blog-Topf and withherein hello to the group. ;)
3athletisches und Triathletisches
3athletisches-und-triathletisches.blogspot.com
data.author: Mike Micho

data.text: I would, don‚Äôt even ask, just roll it in
data.author: Clinton Mason

data.text: We've taken 2 recumbent trikes into hotel rooms. No problems
data.author: Geoff Press

data.text: If it‚Äôll fit. My wife and I took our bikes on a trip once and they wouldn‚Äôt fit in the tiny elevator, so the hotel staff let us store them in a maintenance room.
data.author: Greg Laycock

data.text: Here in Bordeaux France. 1st floor request
data.author: Philip Donahue

data.text: In France never a problem.
data.author: Martin Clarke

data.text: Claim it as your "comfort companion."
data.author: Dan Hurley

data.text: Had two hostels in Los Angeles, CA, USA last week refuse to allow me to bring bike inside or store it in any way. I had reservations, so they could charge me anyway, but I stayed elsewhere.
data.author: Rob  Marines
